text: About mid-way into January I wrote a post about how TorilMUD, an online text based game based in Forgotten Realms and very much the inspiration for EverQuest, had decided to pursue some new content features for its small but loyal player base. TorilMUD – Since 1993… or 1996… or 2003… a long time Not bad for a game past the 30 year mark. (I count from the 1993 launch of SojournMUD and not the 1996 fork that produced Duris and TorilMUD, because TorilMUD was the continuation of the original for all practical measures.  But even the fork will be 30 years in the past soon enough.) Anyway, an update appeared this past week that announced the launch of the first event using the new campaign and encounter features.  It kicked off on Thursday with the following note: Campaign Overview Bosses: Four tough encounters spread across existing zones. Group: Intended for groups of 10+ players. Attempt Limit: Complete the campaign once per week. Duration: Weekly reset every Wednesday morning. Shop: Spend your void shard currency (and craft your relic) at The Darkened Lens, in Baldur’s Gate. Command: Use the new campaign command to active list campaigns and view details on their current progress. Curious to see the in-game information, I logged in to try the new “campaign” command, which showed me the following: Sub-commands: list - list active world campaigns info <campaign> - show details on a campaign Well, that was pretty normal, the need to add additional parameters.  “Campaign List” gave me the current active campaigns, of which there are exactly one at the moment. Active Campaigns: -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- The Call of the Void Stage: The Harbinger's Wrath I followed on with “campaign info call of the void” -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- The Call of the Void -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- Stage : The Harbinger's Wrath Type : World Reset : Weekly -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- Campaign description -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- The Call of the Void is a campaign of cosmic horror, where the Forgotten Realms teeter on the brink of annihilation. From the far reaches of the void, emissaries of Acamar, the Star-That-Devours, have begun their incursion, spreading corruption and seeking to amass power to consume all creation. Thalgron the Watcher, a warlock of Hadar, seeks to halt Acamar's rise from his sanctuary in Baldur's Gate. He offers forbidden knowledge, and the promise of a powerful relic to those who aid his cause. -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- Stage: The Harbinger's Wrath -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- The emissaries' fall heralds the arrival of Acamar's ultimate champion. A terrifying Harbinger descends, bearing the full weight of the void's hunger. Among the ruins of the elven empire's greatest city, ancient wards flicker and fail as something vast and hungry stirs. Defeat it, and drive Acamar and his devouring void back to the shadows. -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- That is the tale behind the campaign.  There were also a couple of interesting points from the announcement. Increased Difficulty The new bosses use the new encounter settings, which gives them: Higher health pools Special immunities Unique and deadly powers Expect a challenge, so group up and plan carefully! Loot Details: Personal loot – no bidding required. Most rewards can drop from any of the bosses. Each boss drops void shard currency to everyone in the group. Increased win chances with each boss defeated. The increased difficulty aspect of this is no surprise.  As happens with all PvE content, players in TorilMUD have optimized to the point that raiding Tiamat, once an event where you might not even get past the initial guardians, is not run regularly. So part of this was clearly to create a greater challenge for the current player base. Meanwhile, the introduction of personal loot is something new.  Many were the runs back in the day when I bid on something only to lose the roll and walk away empty handed.  Trends from MMORPGs are finding their way back to the origins of the genre. Anyway, it looks like a new era has dawned at TorilMUD. html:
About mid-way into January I wrote a post about how TorilMUD, an online text based game based in Forgotten Realms and very much the inspiration for EverQuest, had decided to pursue some new content features for its small but loyal player base.

TorilMUD – Since 1993… or 1996… or 2003… a long time

Not bad for a game past the 30 year mark.

(I count from the 1993 launch of SojournMUD and not the 1996 fork that produced Duris and TorilMUD, because TorilMUD was the continuation of the original for all practical measures.  But even the fork will be 30 years in the past soon enough.)

Anyway, an update appeared this past week that announced the launch of the first event using the new campaign and encounter features.  It kicked off on Thursday with the following note:

Campaign Overview

  • Bosses: Four tough encounters spread across existing zones.
  • Group: Intended for groups of 10+ players.
  • Attempt Limit: Complete the campaign once per week.
  • Duration: Weekly reset every Wednesday morning.
  • Shop: Spend your void shard currency (and craft your relic) at The Darkened Lens, in Baldur’s Gate.
  • Command: Use the new campaign command to active list campaigns and view details on their current progress.

Curious to see the in-game information, I logged in to try the new “campaign” command, which showed me the following:

Sub-commands:

list - list active world campaigns
info <campaign> - show details on a campaign

Well, that was pretty normal, the need to add additional parameters.  “Campaign List” gave me the current active campaigns, of which there are exactly one at the moment.

Active Campaigns:
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
The Call of the Void Stage: The Harbinger's Wrath

I followed on with “campaign info call of the void”

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
The Call of the Void
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
Stage : The Harbinger's Wrath
Type : World
Reset : Weekly
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
Campaign description
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
The Call of the Void is a campaign of cosmic horror, where the Forgotten Realms 
teeter on the brink of annihilation. From the far reaches of the void, 
emissaries of Acamar, the Star-That-Devours, have begun their incursion, 
spreading corruption and seeking to amass power to consume all creation. 
Thalgron the Watcher, a warlock of Hadar, seeks to halt Acamar's rise from his 
sanctuary in Baldur's Gate. He offers forbidden knowledge, and the promise of a 
powerful relic to those who aid his cause.
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
Stage: The Harbinger's Wrath
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
The emissaries' fall heralds the arrival of Acamar's ultimate champion. A 
terrifying Harbinger descends, bearing the full weight of the void's hunger. 
Among the ruins of the elven empire's greatest city, ancient wards flicker and 
fail as something vast and hungry stirs. Defeat it, and drive Acamar and his 
devouring void back to the shadows.
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

That is the tale behind the campaign.  There were also a couple of interesting points from the announcement.

  • Increased Difficulty
    • The new bosses use the new encounter settings, which gives them:
      • Higher health pools
      • Special immunities
      • Unique and deadly powers
    • Expect a challenge, so group up and plan carefully!
  • Loot Details:
    • Personal loot – no bidding required.
    • Most rewards can drop from any of the bosses.
    • Each boss drops void shard currency to everyone in the group.
    • Increased win chances with each boss defeated.

The increased difficulty aspect of this is no surprise.  As happens with all PvE content, players in TorilMUD have optimized to the point that raiding Tiamat, once an event where you might not even get past the initial guardians, is not run regularly.

So part of this was clearly to create a greater challenge for the current player base.

Meanwhile, the introduction of personal loot is something new.  Many were the runs back in the day when I bid on something only to lose the roll and walk away empty handed.  Trends from MMORPGs are finding their way back to the origins of the genre.

Anyway, it looks like a new era has dawned at TorilMUD.
